citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an expired medication for the facility’s spider monkey was comingled with non-expired
medications ready for use. The veterinarian stated that the spider monkey was currently receiving the medication and
didn’t realize it was expired. Expired medical products may lose their effectiveness and may not assist the animal in
recovery from illness and injury or could leave the animal without proper protection against serious and deadly diseases.
Each exhibitor shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and prevent diseases and injuries. Expired
medication should be properly disposed of. The licensee must ensure that all medical products being maintained for use
at the facility are current and have not expired in order to support the health and well-being of the animals. Corrected at
the time of inspection.

-The Giraffes’ “day” feeders have several exposed nails and deteriorating wood sections. Sharp points, particularly those
in areas that animals frequently contact, increase the risk of animal injury.
-In the indoor lion housing enclosure, there are several rusted, sharp, and rough metal edges along the wooden platforms.
Excessive amounts of rust affect the structural strength. Sharp points can pose injury risks to the animals.
-The hoof stock barn has several areas of deteriorating and damaged wood sections. The deteriorated wood sections
pose a potential hazard to the animals housed within.
Facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. The
licensee must ensure structural elements shall be sound and in good repair, free from hazardous conditions such as
sharp edges, nails, splinters, or loose, rusty, or deteriorated materials. Correction Date: March 4, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
GWENDALYN MAGINNIS, Nonhuman Primate Field Specialist
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection, an expired medication for the facility’s spider monkey was comingled with non-expired 
medications ready for use. The veterinarian stated that the spider monkey was currently receiving the medication and 
didn’t realize it was expired. Expired medical products may lose their effectiveness and may not assist the animal in 
recovery from illness and injury or could leave the animal without proper protection against serious and deadly diseases. 
Each exhibitor shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and prevent diseases and injuries. Expired 
medication should be properly disposed of. The licensee must ensure that all medical products being maintained for use 
at the facility are current and have not expired in order to support the health and well-being of the animals. Corrected at 
the time of inspection. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
-The Giraffes’ “day” feeders have several exposed nails and deteriorating wood sections. Sharp points, particularly those 
in areas that animals frequently contact, increase the risk of animal injury.  
 
-In the indoor lion housing enclosure, there are several rusted, sharp, and rough metal edges along the wooden platforms. 
Excessive amounts of rust affect the structural strength. Sharp points can pose injury risks to the animals.  
 
-The hoof stock barn has several areas of deteriorating and damaged wood sections. The deteriorated wood sections 
pose a potential hazard to the animals housed within.  
 
Facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. The 
licensee must ensure structural elements shall be sound and in good repair, free from hazardous conditions such as 
sharp edges, nails, splinters, or loose, rusty, or deteriorated materials. Correction Date: March 4, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

Additional Inspectors: 
GWENDALYN MAGINNIS, Nonhuman Primate Field Specialist 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
